title-group.article-title: Heart rate variability to assess ventilatory thresholds: reliable in cardiac disease?

article-meta.aff: 1EA 3920 “Physiopathologie Cardiovasculaire et Prévention”, Université de Franche Comté, Besançon, France.
2Clinical Investigation Centre Inserm CIT 808, Besançon University Hospital, Besançon, France.
3EA 4267 “Sciences Séparatives Biologiques et Pharmaceutiques”, Université de Franche Comté, Besançon, France.
4EA 3813 “Laboratoire des Adaptations Physiologiques aux Activités Physiques”, Université de Poitiers, Poitiers, France.
5Centre de Réadaptation Cardiovasculaire Bois Gibert, Ballan Miré, France.

author-notes.corresp: Laurent Mourot, Explorations Fonctionnelles Respiratoires, Hôpital St Jacques − Arsenal, F-25030 Besançon Cedex, France Email: laurent.mourot@univ-fcomte.fr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The European Society of Cardiology 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Background: The first (VT1) and second (VT2) ventilatory thresholds are landmarks to tailor exercise rehabilitation in coronary artery disease (CAD) or chronic heart failure (CHF). Methods allowing VT1 and VT2 determination based on heart rate variability (HRV) have been proposed but not yet evaluated in these patients.
Design: To determine the heart rate (HR) associated with VT1 and VT2 by three methods of HRV analyses.

Methods: Fourteen CHF and 24 CAD patients performed an exercise test on a cycle ergometer (10 -W every minute until exhaustion). VT1 and VT2 were determined with the ‘respiratory equivalent’ method. HR at VT1 was determined with the standard deviation (SD) of R⊟R intervals (VTSD) and of the instantaneous beat-to-beat variability of the Poincaré plot method (VTPoincaré). HR at VT1 and VT2 was determined through a time-varying HRV analysis method (VTTV1 and VTTV2, respectively).

Results: HR at VTSD was significantly higher than HR at VT1. No significant differences were observed between HR at VTPoincaré, VTTV1, and at VT1, nor between HR at VTTV2 and VT2. HR at VTSD, VTPoincaré, and VT1 were significantly correlated, but with a low r2 value and a large mean HR difference. With the time-varying method, the mean HR difference was lower than 5% and the correlation coefficients were higher (especially for VTTV2).

Conclusions: SD and Poincaré plot methods lead to substantial inaccuracy in HR estimates. The time-varying HRV analysis led to strong correlation coefficients and low limits of agreement. Therefore, this method may be a promising, low-cost tool for non-invasive assessment of the ventilatory thresholds in cardiac disease.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The benefit of exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation is well established and physical activity is a recognized intervention recommended for prevention in coronary heart disease (CAD) and chronic heart failure (CHF).1–3 However, determining the appropriate exercise intensity remains a challenge. For both efficiency and safety, the first (VT1) and second (VT2) ventilatory thresholds are indicators of interest that should be determined to help in exercise prescription in cardiac disease.1,4–6 Indeed, there is some concern that exercising above VT1 may induce left ventricular wall stress and function deterioration.7–9 On the other hand, evidence has accumulated about the possibility to train cardiac patients also beyond VT2 without incurring additional risk.1 Hence, an intensity at or below VT1 is appropriate for cardiovascular patients,3,10 with the upper limit of prescriptible aerobic training intensity represented by the critical power,11 which is strictly related to VT2.12 Thus, determining VT1 and VT2 is of primary importance. They are usually assessed during a maximal incremental test with measurements of respiratory gas exchanges.1,6,13–15 However, these measures are limited to specialized centres because of methodological, technical, and financial reasons.

On the other hand, it has been suggested that analysis of heart rate variability (HRV) could be a reliable non‐invasive and low-cost method of assessing VT1 and VT2.16–18 In healthy subjects, VT1 has been successfully determined from HRV with time domain18 and the Poincaré plot19 analyses while both VT1 and VT2 could be determined from spectral analysis.16,17 To our knowledge, only one study has used time domain and Poincaré plot HRV analyses for determining VT1 patients (type 2 diabetes).20 No study used one of these three methods with cardiac patients.

The aim of this study was to determine the heart rate associated with VT1 and VT2 by means of HRV analysis and to compare it with the more traditional respiratory determination in a sample of CHF and CAD patients. For this purpose, VT1 was assessed with HRV analyses based on time domain (standard deviation of R⊟R intervals - VTSD)18,20 and the nonlinear Poincaré plot analyses (VTPoincaré),19,20 and VT1 and VT2 were assessed with a time-varying HRV analysis (VTTV1 and VTTV2).16,17 The tested hypothesis was that the time-varying HRV analysis method, which is a method integrating both autonomic nervous system and breathing16,17 information, could allow the ventilatory thresholds to be assessed with sufficient precision to permit its use in clinical routine in cardiac patients.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p:
This study involved 14 male patients with stable CHF patients with impaired systolic function (CHF) and 24 male patients with stabilized coronary artery disease and preserved left ventricular function (CAD). The patients’ main characteristics are presented in Table 1. CAD patients had preserved left systolic function (ejection fraction >50%) and were referred for cardiac rehabilitation after an acute coronary syndrome with or without ST segment elevation. CHF patients had left ventricular systolic dysfunction defined by an ejection fraction ≤40%. The mean values for the left ventricular diastolic volume, the left ventricular systolic volume, and the left ventricular ejection fraction were 60.7 ± 4.8 mm, 43.9 ± 8.0 mm, and 32.7 ± 5.3%, respectively. A coronary angiography was performed in all patients. Patients were included if their clinical condition had been stable for at least 3 weeks and if they had stable ECG sinus rhythm. Exclusion criteria were contraindications to exercise stress testing or stress test stopped for complications such as early residual myocardial ischaemia or complex ventricular arrhythmia. The study protocol complied with the declaration of Helsinki and was reviewed and accepted by the ethical committee of Tours (France). The subjects were informed about the study procedure and gave their written informed consent. Table 1.
Patients’ characteristics

Age (year) 58 ± 11 53 ± 9

Power output (W) 105.9 ± 28.3 137.8 ± 30.4
Values are mean ± standard deviation or %. V; O2, oxygen uptake.

sec.title: Testing procedures
sec.p: Each patient was evaluated in a way similar to that already described.21 Symptom-limited exercise tests were conducted in an upright position on a cycle ergometer (ERG 900, GE Medical System, CASE Exercise Testing System Case, Milwakee, WI, USA). A ramp protocol was used with a 10 -W increase every minute until exhaustion. Achievement of the peak effort was assumed in the presence of at least one of the following criteria: failure of oxygen uptake (V;O2) and/or heart rate to increase with further increases in work rate; peak respiratory exchange ratio (V;CO2/V;O2 >1.10⊟1.15).6 Peak oxygen uptake (V;O2peak) was measured breath-by-breath using a Vmax Spectra system (SensorMedics Corporation, Yorba Linda, CA, USA). The peak values reported in Table 1 were averaged over 1 min.

sec.title: Ventilatory thresholds assessment from respiratory measurements
sec.p: VT1 and VT2 were determined with the ‘respiratory equivalent’ method, based on breath by breath measures of V;O2, carbon dioxide production (V;CO2) and ventilation (V;E) with the values being averaged every 10 seconds. The V;E/V;O2 and V;E/V;CO2 ratios were plotted against time during the incremental exercise test. VT1 corresponds to a first nonlinear increase in the V;E/V;O2 curve while the V;E/V;CO2 slope remains constant. In addition, VT2 is indicated by the nonlinear increase in the V;E/V;CO2 curve concomitant to a second strong increase in V;E/V;O2 with further increase in exercise intensity.1,15 We chose this method because it was proposed that the ventilatory equivalent method appeared to yield the best results13 and a 10 W/min protocol during bicycle exercise appears convenient for the determination of the ventilatory thresholds.22

sec.title: HRV analysis
sec.p: R⊟R series were extracted from a standard ECG (Vista Holter NOVACOR, Rueil, Malmaison, France). Occasional ectopic beats were visually identified and manually replaced with interpolated adjacent R⊟R-interval values.

sec.title: Time-domain and Poincaré plot analyses
sec.p:
The R⊟R intervals were grouped in 1-min sequences for the analyses. The standard deviation of R⊟R intervals (SD) was calculated and plotted against time. A visual interpretation was then made to locate the point at which there was no further decline in SD. This HRV deflection point was defined as VTSD (Figure 1).18,20 Figure 1.
Typical example of the first and second threshold determination by the three heart rate variability methods in a coronary patient. VTPoincaré is the first threshold determined by the Poincaré plot analysis made every minute and was determined when the difference between the SD1 of two consecutive stages was lower than 1 ms (black circles and short dash line). VTSD is the first threshold determined by standard deviation of R-R intervals calculated every minute and was located at the point at which there was no further decline in SD (black triangles and long dash line). VTTV1 and VTTV2 are the first and second thresholds determined by the time-varying spectral analysis, and corresponded to the first nonlinear increase in Ln(fHFm × HFp) after it had reached a minimum and to the final abrupt increase in the Ln(fHFm×HFp), respectively (solid line). In this patient, the heart rate at the first and second ventilator threshold determined by the ‘respiratory equivalent’ method were 84 and 104 bpm, respectively.

The Poincaré plot is a diagram (scatter gram) in which each R⊟R interval is plotted as a function of the previous one. A quantitative analysis of the Poincaré plot was performed on the R⊟R interval time series and the standard deviation of the instantaneous beat-to-beat variability of the data (SD1), as an index of parasympathetic modulations, was calculated from each individual scatter gram.23 The VTPoincaré was determined when the difference between the SD1 of two consecutive stages was lower than 1 ms (Figure 1).19,20

sec.title: Time-varying spectral analysis
sec.p: It is known that, at rest, HRV mostly depends on autonomic activity24 while during exercise, the short-term variability of R⊟R intervals is more tightly related to breathing patterns.17 Because of cardiorespiratory coupling between HRV and ventilation, both the mean peak of high-frequency (HF) power (fHF) and the absolute HF power (HFp) derived from the spectral analysis of HRV are governed by breathing frequency and breathing depth (tidal volume).25 The instantaneous high frequency power (HFp) trend as a function of time and frequency over the entire exercise period was calculated from R⊟R-interval series using a time varying short-term Fourier transform method with 64-s moving windows. A time shift of 3 s was chosen between two successive spectrogram windows (Kubios HRV Analysis Software 2.0, Kuopio, Finland). HFp range was extended from resting recordings (>0.15⊟0.5 Hz to >0.15⊟1.8 Hz) in order to remain in the high breathing frequency ranges reached at high exercise intensity.16 Fitting the mean peak of high-frequency power (fHF) to a third-order model allowed a modelled fHF (fHFm) to be obtained by automatically corrected artefacts (Sigmaplot 8.0, ESPSS Science, Chicago, IL, USA). This procedure increases the association between fHF and breathing frequency.16 The fHFm×HFp product was then calculated. The fHFm×HFp was finally log transformed to increase the readiness of its instantaneous changes over time [Ln(fHFm×HFp)]. The first (VTTV1) as well as the second (VTTV2) thresholds were visually determined from the Ln(fHFm×HFp) curve versus time. VTTV1 corresponded to the first nonlinear increase in Ln(fHFm×HFp) after it had reached a minimum. VTTV2 corresponded to the final abrupt increase in Ln(fHFm×HFp) (Figure 1).16,17

Based on the above criteria, two experienced researchers independently and with blinding assessed VT1 and VT2, VTSD and VTPoincaré, and VTTV1 and VTTV2. When there was a disagreement, a third experienced investigator was involved in the process. When he agreed with one investigator, the corresponding threshold was kept.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The method of Bland and Altman26 was used to compare the different methods of assessing heart rate at the ventilatory thresholds and evaluate whether there was agreement or bias. The relationships were initially made using linear regression, and Pearson’s coefficient correlation (r) was expressed. Agreement between the methods was then determined by calculating the difference between the reference method (heart rate at the ventilatory thresholds from gas exchange measurements) and the methods tested (heart rate at the ventilatory thresholds from HRV analyses). The difference was then plotted against the mean of the two methods compared. Limits of agreement were defined as means ± 2SD. The Gaussian distribution of the data was verified by the Kolmogorov⊟Smirnov goodness-of-fit test (Z value <1.0). Statistical significance was assumed for a p-value of less than 0.05 and data are presented as mean ± SD. Statistical analyses were performed using SigmaStat software (SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL, USA).

sec.title: Assessment of heart rate at VT from respiratory measurements
sec.p: In both CAD and CHF, VT1 and VT2 were determined in 100% of the tests with the gas analysis method. The help of a third investigator was required in 10 cases, which amounted to circa 13% of the whole number of ventilatory thresholds determined. For VT1, the HR values were 82.1 ± 10.1 and 88.6 ± 14.8 bpm for CAD and CHF, respectively. For VT2, the HR values were 115.8 ± 21.0 and 112.9 ± 22.5 bpm for CAD and CHF, respectively.

sec.title: Assessment of heart rate at the ventilatory thresholds from HRV analyses
sec.p: In CAD, VTSD was determined in 21 patients (88%), VTPoincaré in 19 patients (79%), VTTV1 in 23 patients (96%), and VTTV2 in 24 patients (100%). The help of a third investigator was required in nine cases (10% of the ventilatory thresholds determined). HR at VTSD, VTPoincaré, VTTV1, and VTTV2 were 106.1 ± 18.8, 88.4 ± 22.2, 85.6 ± 13.9, and 116.0 ± 21.1 bpm, respectively.

In CHF, VTSD was determined in 13 patients (93%), VTPoincaré in 10 patients (71%), VTTV1 in 14 patients (100%), and VTTV2 in 14 patients (100%). The help of a third investigator was required in six cases (12% of the ventilatory thresholds determined). HR at VTSD, VTPoincaré, VTTV1, and VTTV2 were 105.4 ± 21.5, 94.8 ± 16.1, 89.1 ± 14.1, and 115.1 ± 21.5 bpm respectively.

sec.title: Comparisons
sec.p: For both CAD and CHF patients, heart rate at VTSD was higher (p > 0.01) than heart rate at VT1. On the other hand, no significant differences were observed between heart rate at VTPoincaré and VTTV1 and heart rate at VT1, nor between heart rate at VTTV2 and heart rate at the second ventilator threshold (VT2).

Regardless of whether all the patients were taken together or if CAD and CHF patients were separated, heart rate at VTSD and VTPoincaré were significantly correlated to heart rate at VT1, but with a low correlation coefficient, and a large mean heart rate difference and 95% confidence interval (Table 2, Figure 2). Figure 2.
Bland−Altman plot showing individual differences between heart rate at the ventilatory threshold obtained from respiratory measurements and from VTSD, VTSD1, VTTV1, and between heart rate at the second ventilator threshold and VTTV2 (lower plot). All, all patients taken together; CAD, coronary artery disease; CHF, chronic heart failure; VT1 and VT2, first and second ventilatory thresholds; VTSD, VT1 assessment with the standard deviation of R−R intervals analysis; VTPoincaré, VT1 assessment with the Poincaré plot analysis; VTTV1 and VTTV2, VT1 and VT2 assessments with time-varying heart rate variability analysis. Table 2.

On the other hand, biases were lower when using the time-varying HRV analysis method. Indeed, when all patients were taken together, the coefficient correlations were higher (especially for VTTV2) and the mean heart rate difference lower than 5%. The 95% confidence interval remained nevertheless high for VTTV1. The biases were lower for CHF than for CAD patients.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we tested the hypothesis that heart rate variability analysis (and especially time-varying HRV analysis) could allow ventilatory thresholds to be determined in CAD and CHF patients with impaired systolic function. Our results showed that the standard deviation of R⊟R intervals and the standard deviation of the instantaneous beat-to-beat variability of R⊟R intervals (SD1 of the Poincaré plot analysis) are less accurate than time-varying HRV method. They cannot allow the detection of both the first and second ventilatory thresholds whereas it is possible with the time-varying HRV method.

The ventilatory thresholds allow for exercise intensity prescription, even though their physiological and clinical significance is uncertain.22 They are usually determined from respiratory measurements.1,13,14,22,27 In CAD and CHF, a high reproducibility has been found during ramp cycling ergometry for duplicate measurements of cardiopulmonary and haemodynamic variables, including heart rate at ventilatory thresholds.14,28 The determination of these thresholds is recommended both to assess the training effect and to specify training intensity.1,10,29 However, such determination required measurements of respiratory gas exchanges. Consequently, the ventilatory thresholds assessment is limited to some specialized centres. This also hinders the generalization of their assessment for prescription of exercise rehabilitation, especially when long-term home-based programmes are planned.

Other non-invasive and more easily usable methods, based on heart rate recordings and analysis of heart rate variability, have been proposed to identify the ventilatory thresholds and several studies carried out on healthy subjects showed good agreement for heart rate at ventilatory thresholds determined by respiratory measurements and HRV.16–18,20 Although further studies are needed to understand the mechanisms of HRV, HRV is considered valid and is widely used in the acute and chronic evaluation of CAD and CHF patients.30

There are a variety of indexes that can be used to assess HRV. They can be divided into three major categories: time domain, frequency domain and nonlinear domain indexes. In the present study, we tested the evaluation of the ventilatory thresholds through the standard deviation of R⊟R intervals (a time domain index),18,20 the time-varying HRV analysis (frequency domain),16,17 and the standard deviation of the instantaneous beat-to-beat variability of the data (Poincaré plot analyses of HRV, a nonlinear index).19,20 In our results, SD and SD1 led to conspicuous errors in determining VT1. The use of these indexes is based on the idea that vagal R⊟R modulation is no more present beyond VT1.23,31 When these indexes reach low values and do not fall any further (usually, under 3 ms), VT1 is attained. Contrary to the results obtained in the present study, these indexes and VT1 appeared to be linked in previous studies.18–20 On reason may be the fact that in these previous works, the incremental exercises used were based on 3-min stages with calculation of the indexes during the last minute of each stage, whereas we used 1-min stages. Moreover, it has not been conclusively shown that vagal modulation is the mechanism responsible for VT1 and the sole evaluation of parasympathetic activity during incremental exercise seems insufficient to assess VT1 in cardiac patients properly.

On the other hand, better results were obtained with the time-varying method we used. This method computes high frequency power (HFp, index of parasympathetic activity) and the frequency associated with HF (fHF), providing instantaneous breathing frequency without the use of any respiratory device.17 It has been reported that VT1 and VT2 could be determined from breathing frequency only and thus from fHF only because breathing frequency increases when VT1 is exceeded and abruptly increases when VT2 is exceeded.17 Moreover, the thresholds assessment from HRV was more accurate when using the mathematical product of HF by fHF because it also takes into account changes in tidal volume on which HF power depends.17 More detailed discussions have already been provided to explain the method.16,17

Heart rates at the ventilatory thresholds are often used as targets during the training sessions. In this study, the limit of agreement between the ventilatory thresholds from respiratory measurements and the ventilatory thresholds from time-varying analysis was low (2⊟3 bpm). This agreement (less than 5%) was comparable or lower than that obtained in healthy subjects in terms of heart rate,16 oxygen uptake,18 or power output,17 suggesting that this method is promising in assessing heart rate associated with the ventilatory thresholds and thus in guiding the design of exercise intensity in rehabilitation programmes for cardiac patients.

sec.title: Limits
sec.p: Despite a limited number of subjects, we made the distinction between CHF and coronary disease patients (without performing statistical comparisons which would have been of limited robustness). The results were similar in each group, i.e. that time-varying analysis appeared the best method. Nevertheless, the ventilatory thresholds determination through time-varying analysis gave slightly better results in CHF, with lower limits of agreement and a higher number of VT determinations with differences lower than 5 bpm. Also, the judgement of ventilatory thresholds, from respiratory measures or heart rate variability analysis, remains subjective and operator-dependent, even among physicians familiar with the procedure. At least two independent observers are required for a reliable determination14 and sometimes three are indeed involved in the determination. We did not see any difference between the methods we used in the present study (a third investigator was necessary in about 10% of the cases whatever the method). A valid and objective procedure is still lacking for assessing VT from both respiratory measurement and HRV.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, we tested the hypothesis that heart rate at the first and second ventilatory thresholds could be reliably determined through heart rate variability analysis in CAD and CHF patients. We found that indexes derived from time-domain and nonlinear analyses should not be used because of considerable errors in the determination in the heart rate associated with the ventilatory threshold. On the other hand, the method based on time-varying spectral analysis gave strong correlation coefficients and low limits of agreement. These results suggest that HRV may be a promising, low-cost tool for non-invasive assessment of the ventilatory thresholds. Further studies are required to confirm our encouraging results on a larger population, with patients with different kinds of diseases, and with other HRV indexes.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors thank the subjects for their time and cooperation. They also thank Frances Sheppard of the Clinical Investigation Center of the University Hospital of Besançon for correcting and improving the English.

sec.p: This work was supported by the French Ministry of National Education, of Research and of Technology (UPRES EA3920), by the Fédération Française de Cardiologie, and the Fondation de l’Avenir.

sec.title: Conflict of interests
sec.p: No conflict of interest in connection with the submitted article exists.
